round_data.prompt:
You and another agent have to negotiate a division of items between the two of you.
    You are Player 1 and the other agent is Player 2.
    There are 5 types of items, called item 1 through item 5.
    There are 4 units of item 1, 2 units of item 2, 3 units of item 3, 5 units of item 4, 2 units of item 5 to divide.
    Both you and Player 2 have a private value per unit of each item type.
    These values are drawn from a uniform random distribution, ranging from 1 to 101.
    Your private values are 72 for item 1, 64 for item 2, 76 for item 3, 58 for item 4, 10 for item 5.
    You have a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to your total value of all items, which is 954. Player 2 has a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to to their total value of all items.
    Your outside offer value is 586. 

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.98, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

    Please show your reasoning step by step, then provide your action in one of these formats in your response (if you do not do this your response will be invalid):
    {"action": "ACCEPT"} - to accept the current offer
    {"action": "WALK"} - to walk away from negotiations  
    {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [n1, n2, ...]} - where n1, n2, ... are numbers representing the number of units of each item being offered to the other player as part of the counteroffer.

    Any response not in these exact formats will be invalid and treated as a WALK. If you provide a counteroffer, it must be a valid offer, otherwise it will be treated as a WALK.

    It is now round 1.
    
 Negotiation history:

Current offer on the table (the amount of each item being offered to you): None

        What is your action? As the first player, your available actions are:
        - WALK to walk away
        - A list of numbers [n1, n2, ...] representing your initial offer (what you give to Player 2)
round_data.response:
I want to choose an initial offer that (a) gives me more than my outside (disagreement) value of 586 (when I compute my own “worth” for the items I would get) and (b) is “generous” enough to tempt Player 2 to take the deal rather than hope for a better outside offer later. My own per‐unit values are highest for items 1 and 3 (72 and 76, respectively) while item 5 is very cheap (10) and item 4 is “middle‐of‐the‐road” (58). In order to “pay” little in terms of my own utility while “buying” extra quantity for Player 2 we would like to concede items that cost me little. In my view the best “cheap” items to give are all of item 5 (2 units; cost = 2×10 = 20) and as many of item 4 as possible (each unit “costs” me 58). There are 5 units of item 4 available; giving those up costs me 5×58 = 290. Together these concessions cost 20 + 290 = 310. In that case my allocation is everything else:
 • Item 1: all 4 units (4×72 = 288)
 • Item 2: all 2 units (2×64 = 128)
 • Item 3: all 3 units (3×76 = 228)
 • Item 4: 0 units (lost 5 units)
 • Item 5: 0 units (lost 2 units)
So my total “value” is 288 + 128 + 228 = 644, which is above my outside offer of 586.

This offer gives Player 2 the entire stock of items 4 and 5—in my view, “cheap” items that for him will be worth a number of units (7 in total) that in expectation is less than if his private type were high; however, if Player 2’s private values are relatively low he might prefer 7 units from these items rather than risk discounting in later rounds. In any case, while one might ideally like to give 8 “units” so that Player 2’s expected gain (using an average value near 51 per unit) is before his outside offer (~408), it turns out that if I try to give up any extra unit (for example, 1 unit of item 2, costing me 64) my resulting “take‐home” drops to about 954 – (310+64) = 580, which is below my outside offer. Since I have no interest in a deal that leaves me worse off than simply walking away, I must leave my share at least 586. (My current offer yields 644 for me.) 

Thus, even though Player 2 might prefer a “bigger piece” (an 8‐unit bundle) on average, I must start with an offer that does not undermine my fallback. My initial offer is to give Player 2 everything in items 4 and 5 (i.e. 5 and 2 units, respectively). In our protocol the offer is expressed as the list of items I give to Player 2. 

Therefore my response in round 1 is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 0, 5, 2]}

My reasoning is as follows. I first computed that if I received everything I’d get a total present‐value of 436 (i.e. 3·44 + 4·36 + 2·19 + 2·28 + 1·66). Because my fallback (the outside offer) is 124, any deal giving me more than that is better than “walking.” At the same time, my opponent’s private values (drawn from a uniform 1–101 per unit) and his outside offer (drawn uniformly from 1 to his expected total value) suggest that—if he is rational—he will not accept an outcome that gives him little more than his reservation level. In many bargaining settings an initial offer that is “fair” (with a slight advantage to the proposer) may be accepted; an equal–or near–equal split in value is a common starting point.

From my own perspective I estimated that an approximately equal split in our “subjective” values (i.e. around 218 points each from the 436 total) would be a reasonable starting point. However, as the first mover it is typically optimal to obtain a slightly better deal for myself while still giving my opponent a margin to agree rather than walk away (especially as negotiation delays further reduce the effective value through the discount factor, although in round 1 gamma^(0)=1).

Looking at the available items:
 • Item 1: 3 units at 44 each;
 • Item 2: 4 units at 36 each;
 • Item 3: 2 units at 19 each;
 • Item 4: 2 units at 28 each;
 • Item 5: 1 unit at 66.

I then considered a simple offer in which I “give” Player 2 the following allocation: 1 unit of item 1, 2 units of item 2, 1 unit of item 3, 1 unit of item 4, and 1 unit of item 5. Under that proposal I would get the remainder:
 • For item 1: 2 units,
 • item 2: 2 units,
 • item 3: 1 unit,
 • item 4: 1 unit,
 • item 5: 0 units.

My subjective value if this division is agreed becomes:
 • 2×44 = 88 from item 1,
 • 2×36 = 72 from item 2,
 • 1×19 = 19 from item 3,
 • 1×28 = 28 from item 4,
 • 0×66 = 0 from item 5.
 Summing to 88 + 72 + 19 + 28 = 207.

Player 2’s allocated bundle would be (from my own perspective):
 • 1×44 = 44 from item 1,
 • 2×36 = 72 from item 2,
 • 1×19 = 19 from item 3,
 • 1×28 = 28 from item 4,
 • 1×66 = 66 from item 5,
 Totaling 44 + 72 + 19 + 28 + 66 = 229.

Even though these are my own valuations (and his true values will be based on his private numbers), this offer reveals a near–equal split (with slightly more to Player 2 – which is often necessary when one party’s outside option might be high) while still giving me a share (207) well above my fallback (124) and leaving room for potential agreement. Taking into account discounting (which is not an issue in round 1) and the incentive for the opponent to get more than his outside offer, I believe this is a reasonable starting point.

Thus, my action (with a valid offer listing the number of units given to Player 2) is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 2, 1, 1, 1]}

I’ll explain my thought process briefly. My goal is to propose an initial division that makes the deal immediately acceptable to Player 2 while securing me a payoff much above my outside option of 287. (Recall that if no deal is reached, each player gets their outside‐offer value; for me that is 287.) I also want to “keep” more of the items that are most valuable to me—especially item 4 (worth 95 per unit) and to a lesser extent items 1 and 2 (worth 46–47 each)—and be more generous with the items I care less about (item 3 is only worth 28 per unit and item 5 is 45 per unit). 

A rough idea is to ensure that, in expectation, Player 2’s share is at least as good as what he would expect if negotiations continued (typically his outside offer is drawn uniformly from 1 up to his full‐pie value; given the totals this tends to be around half his full value). My full “pie” (by my own values) is 1057. A naïve even split in value would give about 528–529 to each. I want slightly more for myself but must “buy” immediate acceptance by giving Player 2 a share that in his unknown private valuations would be competitive with his future prospects. (Note that waiting costs both players a factor γ = 0.98 per extra round.) 

Since I do not know Player 2’s private numbers I assume (based on the uniform distribution) that his per‐unit averages are on the order of about 51 per unit. In order for him to be tempted to accept in round 1 (without discounting), he should expect roughly 10–11 “good” units of value. A good approach from my side is to give him all of the low‐value item for me: item 3 (all 3 units) and all of item 5 (all 6 units) so that his total allocation has 3 + 6 = 9 items; then give him a little more from one or two of the more “neutral” items so that the total “unit count” (and roughly expected value) gets near 11. For example, awarding him 1 unit of item 1 and 1 unit of item 2 brings his “basket” to 11 units. (I keep all of item 4 because it is very expensive for me.) 

Under this proposal the division is as follows:
 • Offer to Player 2: item1: 1, item2: 1, item3: 3, item4: 0, item5: 6.
 • Consequently, I get: item1: 4, item2: 3, item3: 0, item4: 3, item5: 0.
My own payoff (using my own per‐unit valuations) is:
 4×46 + 3×47 + 3×95 = 184 + 141 + 285 = 610,
which is well above my outside offer value.
In an expected “average opponent” scenario (with per‐unit value roughly 51) the offer to Player 2 would be worth approximately:
 1×51 + 1×51 + 3×51 + 6×51 = 51 + 51 + 153 + 306 = 561.
That is somewhat above an even 50–50 split and should be enough to induce early acceptance given the discount factor and the risks of waiting.

Thus, in round 1 my move is to propose this counteroffer.

Step 1. My total “pie” in my own terms (my undiscounted value if I got everything) is 
  4×41 + 4×52 + 5×18 + 2×54 + 2×34 = 638.
If no deal is reached, I receive my outside option of 492. Thus any deal I agree to must give me at least 492 in my own valuation. In other words, I cannot “sacrifice” more than 638 – 492 = 146 of my potential value in any division.

Step 2. Although I do not know Player 2’s private values, those are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 so that the per‐unit “average” is about 51. (By contrast, my values are known: 41, 52, 18, 54, 34 for items 1 through 5.) In a bargaining situation each player’s “reservation” is the value of their outside offer. (My outside offer is 492; Player 2’s is unknown but it will on average be roughly half of their full‐pie; note the full pie for Player 2 would be different from 638.) Thus, to get a deal, I must propose an allocation giving Player 2 at least as much as his outside option (or what he expects to get in future rounds). Practically, that means my initial offer must “sweeten” the deal for him sufficiently even though I wish to keep as much as possible.

Step 3. To decide what items to “sacrifice” to him, I look at the “cost” to me (my value per unit) versus the likely benefit to him (expected value ≈ 51 per unit). The lower my value for a unit the “cheaper” it is for me to hand that unit over:
  • Item 3 costs me only 18 per unit (and gives an expected 51 to him) – the best ratio.
  • Next best is item 5: my value 34 compared to an expected 51.
  • Items 1, 2, and 4 have higher costs (41, 52, and 54, respectively) relative to the “average” of about 51.
Thus, if I want to “sacrifice” value to give him a deal he may accept, I should use as many units of item 3 as available and then add some units of item 5 if allowed by my “sacrifice budget” of 146.

Step 4. My goal is to keep myself at or above 492. To maximize his “extra” while not falling below that, I wish to give away up to (but not exceeding) 146 points of my value.
  – If I give away all 5 units of item 3 that “cost” me 5×18 = 90, I still “have” 146 − 90 = 56 points of margin.
  – I cannot give 2 whole units of item 5 because that would be 2×34 = 68 (and 90 + 68 = 158, which would leave me with only 638 − 158 = 480, below my outside offer).
  – One unit of item 5 “costs” me 34, so giving that plus all of item 3 uses 90 + 34 = 124, leaving me with 638 − 124 = 514. (I could alternatively consider, say, all of item 3 plus 1 unit of item 1, but 90 + 41 = 131 leaves me with 507 – a higher outcome for me than if I sacrifice 124.)
I prefer to maximize his “slice” (making the deal more attractive for him) without dropping my own outcome below what I can get otherwise. Although ideally I might “sacrifice” the full 146, because of the indivisible units I cannot hit that exactly. One “good” candidate is to give him items that cost me 140 to leave me with 638 − 140 = 498 (which is above my outside option) while providing him with a bundle that in my estimation is attractive.

Step 5. One such offer is to give him 4 units of item 3 (costing me 4×18 = 72) plus 2 units of item 5 (costing me 2×34 = 68). Total “sacrifice” cost is 72 + 68 = 140 (well within my 146 margin). That leaves me with a bundle worth 638 − 140 = 498, above my outside offer. (The remaining units go to me: I keep all of item 1 and item 2, all of item 4, and the “leftover” unit of item 3 since there are 5 in total.) From my perspective the bundle I’m granting Player 2 has an expected value of about 4×51 (from item 3) plus 2×51 (from item 5) which is approximately 306—this may be low relative to his unknown reservation, but as a first strong (and aggressive) offer I must start somewhere.

Step 6. Given this reasoning, my initial offer as Player 1 is to propose that Player 2 receives:

  • 2 units of item 5.
This is submitted as my offer to Player 2.

(I do not know their exact values.) In this three‐round negotiation the deal reached in round 1 isn’t discounted, so I want to “anchor” with an aggressive yet “fair” offer that gives the other player enough so that they would be tempted to agree rather than risk a counteroffer in a later round (which would be discounted by γ = 0.98).

One natural idea is to divide each item roughly equally. The items and quantities available are:
 • Item 1: 4 units
 • Item 2: 4 units
 • Item 3: 4 units
 • Item 4: 6 units
 • Item 5: 5 units

Given that I value these items at 54, 63, 85, 33, and 59 per unit (respectively) the “fair” division (if we split the units approximately in half) would be, for example, to give the opponent 2, 2, and 2 units of items 1, 2, and 3. For item 4 (6 units) a half split is 3 units each. For item 5 (5 units) there is an odd number; while “fair” might be 2.5 each, I must choose an integer split. Because I get more value out of item 5 (59 per unit) than the opponent is expected to get on average, I elect to give the opponent 2 units and keep 3.

 • Item 5: 5 – 2 = 3 units (value: 3×59 = 177)
 Total value for me = 108 + 126 + 170 + 99 + 177 = 680

This gives me a safety margin of 30 above my outside offer of 650. (I cannot concede another full unit in any item without dropping below 650 since the “cheapest” item to me is item 4 at 33 per unit.) Even though an “even‐dividing” of the items might give the opponent roughly equal “quantities,” by conceding any extra unit I would all but risk ending up with a value below my reservation.

So as a first move I propose the split [2,2,2,3,2] (which means I offer the opponent 2 units of items 1, 2, and 3, 3 units of item 4, and 2 units of item 5). In any deal I want my own value (using my private per–unit values) to be at least 471. (If I “keep” a set of items, my value is the sum over items of [my per–unit value × (total units minus the quantity I “give” to Player 2)].)

The full pie (if I got all items) is worth 880 to me. Thus if I get a division that gives me value v, then the “concession” to Player 2 (in my “currency”) is 880–v, and I must have 880–v ≤ 880–471 = 409. (In other words, I cannot “give” away more than 409 value‐points to Player 2, otherwise I’d be doing worse than my outside option.)

I also want the offer to be “attractive” to Player 2. Although I do not know Player 2’s exact private values, I do know that they are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 (so the average per–unit value is about 51). My own values per unit differ by item type:
 • Item 1: 27 (so Player 2’s expected value is relatively higher, about 51 vs. my 27)
 • Item 2: 59 (here I value the item more)
 • Item 3: 20 (again, Player 2’s typical value ~51 is much higher than my 20)
 • Item 4: 7 (a very low value to me compared to an average of about 51)
 • Item 5: 77 (I view this as highly valuable; Player 2’s average value of 51 makes these more “cheap” for me)

So to get a deal that Player 2 might be inclined to accept, I want to offer them items that I value relatively little (leaving the “precious” ones for myself) and which even under average circumstances might yield them roughly the “reservation” value they expect (which averages around 510 given that the full pie for them is roughly 20×51 = 1020).

One proposal that meets these criteria is to “give” Player 2 items 1, 3, and 4 in full. Let’s see the numbers:
 • Item 1: All 3 units are given. To me that “costs” 3×27 = 81.
 • Item 3: All 4 units are given. “Cost” = 4×20 = 80.
 • Item 4: All 3 units are given. “Cost” = 3×7 = 21.
The total “cost” is 81 + 80 + 21 = 182 (well below my maximum “concession budget” of 409). 

This leaves me with:
 • Item 2: all 4 units (worth me 4×59 = 236)
 • Item 5: all 6 units (worth me 6×77 = 462)
So the total for me would be 236 + 462 = 698, comfortably above my outside offer of 471.

What might Player 2 see? Even if their private values differ from mine, note that on average they expect about 51 per unit. Receiving items 1, 3, and 4 in full amounts to about 10 units in total. On average that is about 10×51 = 510—a number close to what one might expect from their outside alternative. (Of course, sometimes they might value these items even more relative to others, which gives them extra incentive to reach an agreement.)

This offer gives me a very favorable outcome, while it offers Player 2 a package that in expectation is at or around what they could get outside (and also spares delays and discounting in later rounds).

For example, if we split the overall 1201 “pie” roughly so that Player 2 gets about 500 (by my measure) and I get about 700, I’m improving on my outside offer by a respectable margin (700 versus 496) while offering Player 2 something they may well prefer over waiting.

I will now explain my reasoning.

We are in the final (round 3) of negotiations. If we accept the current offer on the table (which is what Player 2 last proposed) we would receive the bundle [1, 1, 3, 2, 1] for items 1–5 respectively. Using our private per‐unit values, the undiscounted value of that bundle is

  24·1 + 57·1 + 77·3 + 50·2 + 85·1 = 24 + 57 + 231 + 100 + 85 = 497.

Since we are in round 3 the deal would be discounted by γ^(3–1) = 0.98² ≈ 0.9604, so our “present value” would be about 497×0.9604 ≈ 477. By contrast our private outside offer is 496 (and this “reservation” is not discounted). Thus if we accept the current offer our “discounted deal” value is well below what we can secure by walking away.

Being the proposer in the final round we have some bargaining power. We can make a counteroffer that (if accepted) will give us a better allocation – one for which our “raw” (undiscounted) value is sufficiently above 496/0.9604 ≈ 517 so that, once discounted, we are better off than walking away. At the same time we must give Player 2 enough in the deal so that they are willing to accept rather than resorting to their outside offer. (Recall that a rejection would end the negotiation and we’d both get our outside offers.)

Notice that under the current offer Player 2 would “get” the complementary bundle. Since the total supplies are [2, 4, 5, 4, 4] the complement to [1, 1, 3, 2, 1] is [1, 3, 2, 2, 3]. That deal “favors” Player 2 in items 2 and 5. To swing the deal in our favor we want to reassign a little bit from Player 2 to ourselves. For example, if we reduce Player 2’s allocation on a high‐value commodity (and for us one of the highest is item 5, worth 85 per unit) by one unit, our share will be the complement of a counteroffer that gives Player 2, say, [1, 3, 2, 2, 2]. Then our allocation becomes the complement:
  Item 1: 2–1 = 1  
  Item 2: 4–3 = 1  
  Item 3: 5–2 = 3  
  Item 4: 4–2 = 2  
  Item 5: 4–2 = 2

Our bundle is then [1, 1, 3, 2, 2] with undiscounted value

  24·1 + 57·1 + 77·3 + 50·2 + 85·2  
   = 24 + 57 + 231 + 100 + 170  
   = 582.

Discounting that at 0.9604 gives about 582×0.9604 ≈ 559, well above the 496 we’d receive by walking.

Comparing Player 2’s shares under the two deals: under the current offer they would get [1, 3, 2, 2, 3] while in our counteroffer they would receive [1, 3, 2, 2, 2] – a reduction of 1 unit in item 5. (Given that players’ private values are drawn uniformly between 1 and 101 the loss in that item should be “small” relative to the potential gain to us.) In a final‐round bargaining situation it is standard to “squeeze” a little extra when you know your own reservation is above the current deal’s payoff. (Of course, Player 2 might reject if they require that extra unit, but if they don’t accept then we’d both get our outside offers, yielding 496 for us. Therefore, making a counteroffer that improves our outcome if accepted is strictly better than accepting an offer worth only ≈477.)

For these reasons I choose to propose a counteroffer. In the counteroffer the numbers represent the number of units I would give to Player 2. I propose to offer Player 2 [1, 3, 2, 2, 2] (which is valid since none exceed total availability), leaving myself the complementary bundle [1, 1, 3, 2, 2] which (after discount) yields a value of about 559 – clearly better than our outside offer of 496.

Thus, my action is to make the following counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 3, 2, 2, 2]}

So if I took everything I’d get 1743. In order for a deal to be better for me than my fallback of 1115 I must “keep” items (the complement of what I offer you) worth at least 1115 by my own weighting. In other words the total “cost” of what I give you (measured by my private values) can be at most 1743–1115 = 628.

Because I do not know your (Player2’s) private values – they are each drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 – I estimate that your expected per‐unit value is roughly 51. Thus, if I give you certain items, you expect to “earn” about 51 per unit on average. In formulating my proposal I want to “spend” as little of my 628 “concession budget” (in my value terms) as possible while giving you items that – when priced on your likely scale – come out as attractive compared to your own outside offer.

Looking at my value profile the “cheapest” items for me are item4 (each unit costs me only 29 even though you’d get roughly 51 in expectation, a “conversion factor” of about 51/29 ≃ 1.76). Next best is item5 (cost 63 for me, conversion ≃ 0.81) and then item3 (69 for me, conversion ≃ 0.74). To try to “buy off” you I want to give you as many of the low‐cost items as I can while still keeping my total above 1115.

One attractive “line” of play is to give you all of item4 and all of item5. That uses:
 • item4: all 6 units → my “loss” = 6×29 = 174 
 • item5: all 6 units → my “loss” = 6×63 = 378 
Together that costs me 174+378 = 552. I then keep a value of 1743–552 = 1191, which is comfortably above my fallback of 1115.

However, based on typical outside offers on your side (knowing that your full‐bundle total in expectation is around 1377, so your “fallback” might be roughly half that, maybe in the 650–690 range), 552 (which in “expected opponent dollars” would roughly be 6×51+6×51 = 612) might be a little too low an offer from your perspective. I have a remaining “concession capacity” of 628–552 = 76 (measured in my own values) that I can “spend” on giving you a little extra. The next best item for me is item3, whose units cost 69 to me but are worth (on average) about 51 to you. One extra unit of item3 – thereby giving you one more unit – costs me 69 but boosts your expected total by about 51. (I cannot “fractionally” concede an item, so I must choose between 0 or at least 1 extra unit here.) Adding 1 unit of item3 increases my “concession” to 552+69 = 621 (which is still within my 628 “budget”) and leaves me with a retention value of 1743–621 = 1122 (a little above my 1115 outside offer). For you, in expectation, that extra unit of item3 adds roughly 51 well‐being units so that you’d “see” your offer as giving you about 612+51 = 663 in expected benefit.

which by my own values is 4×81 + 6×87 + 4×69 = 324 + 522 + 276 = 1122 (>1115).

which in expectation (using 51 per unit) is about 51 + 306 + 306 = 663.
Given the uncertainty in your actual private values and outside offer, this is a lean offer designed to win your acceptance while keeping my payoff above my disagreement value. (Of course, if your private number is unusually high you might later reject—but as the proposer I try to extract as much surplus as I can while giving you just enough to (likely) beat your outside option.)

In round 1 no discount is applied (γ^(0)=1), so I must propose a split that gives Player 2 roughly at least as much as his own outside offer (even though his “true” numbers are unknown, his expected total‐value per item is around a mid‐range number, roughly 51 per unit on average). At the same time, I’d like to “claim” the items where my own relative valuation is high compared to the average. For example, I value item 3 at 100 while the average opponent’s unit value would be around 51; similarly, item 2 is worth 86 for me. On the other hand item 4 is worth only 18 to me (and so it is “cheap” for me to give away) and item 1 (57) has a relatively small margin over a likely average 51. Item 5 (79) is moderately better for me than the expected opponent value.

If I make an offer giving the opponent too little overall, even if I get a much better payoff (for example, keeping all of item 2, item 3, and most of item 5) the opponent might prefer his outside offer of 315. Thus a safe idea is to “just barely” guarantee him an expected value above 315. (Approximating with an average of ~51/value per unit, the opponent needs roughly 6 – 7 “units” of value. I can “buy” this largely with items that aren’t too precious to me – like item 4 (which I only value at 18) and, if needed, some units of item 1.)

One candidate I considered was to assign to Player 2:
 • item 1: 2 units (leaving me 1 unit; cost to me = 57, but giving them roughly 2×51=102),
 • item 2: 0 units (so I keep all 3, and I get the high 86/unit),
 • item 3: 0 units (I keep the sole unit, valued at 100 for me),
 • item 4: 1 unit (I give this cheap item entirely – expected ~51),
 • item 5: 4 units (so that from 8 total, I keep 4, and roughly 4×51=204 is expected for him).

Then from the item totals:
 – For item 1 (3 available): 2 go to Player 2 and 1 to me.
 – For item 2 (3 available): I keep all 3.
 – For item 3 (1 available): I keep it.
 – For item 4 (1 available): Player 2 gets the full 1.
 – For item 5 (8 available): 4 go to Player 2 and 4 to me.

My own allocation is then:
 • item 1: 1 unit (1×57 = 57)
 • item 2: 3 units (3×86 = 258)
 • item 3: 1 unit (1×100 = 100)
 • item 4: 0 units (0×18 = 0)
 • item 5: 4 units (4×79 = 316)

 • item 1: 2×51 = 102

 • item 5: 4×51 = 204
Totaling around 102 + 51 + 204 = 357, which is comfortably above his outside option of 315. (I leave out item 2 and item 3 from his share because I want to secure my high‐value items.)

This division has the advantage that I “capture” the most valuable parts relative to the expected opponent values while giving the opponent just enough to likely accept rather than take his outside offer. (There is some uncertainty about his private numbers, but this balanced offer moves the negotiation in my favor.)

Thus my initial offer (which is the list of numbers representing the items I give to Player 2) is: [2, 0, 0, 1, 4].

Although I do not know Player 2’s private values, they are drawn uniformly between 1 and 101, so (on average) each unit is worth about 51 to them. Their total pie in expectation (over all items) is roughly 19 × 51 ≈ 969, and their private outside offer will be somewhere in the range [1,969] (with average ≈485). So in equilibrium one would expect a roughly “fair‐sized” share of the pie (if we think of the negotiation surplus being split near 50–50) is needed to make the offer attractive.

I also compare my own marginal values. I really like items 1 (52), 2 (56), 4 (54), and especially 5 (83). In contrast, I place only 6 per unit on item 3. Since for Player 2 the average per unit is around 51, item 3 is “cheap” for me but (in expectation) decently valuable for them. For additional concession the “cheapest” (from my point of view) is item 1, since I value it at 52 while the average for Player 2 would be roughly 51 (a tiny difference). I'll explain my thinking.

My goal is to propose an initial split that, in my view, leaves both sides better off than walking away (recall that my outside option is 378). Although I have no direct knowledge of Player 2’s private values and outside offer, I know that on average his per‐unit values are drawn uniformly between 1 and 101 so that his “expected” per‐unit value is roughly 51. Given the total items available (5,8,3,5,8) my total max value is 1016, and his “expected” full‐bundle value is near 1479 with an outside offer drawn uniformly from 1 to that amount (with expected around 740). 

In forming a proposal I want to keep a majority of the items in which I get a “comparative edge.” For example, I get 77 per unit on item 4 while (on average) his is lower. In contrast, my value for items 3 and 5 is relatively low (19 and 14, respectively) compared to the roughly 51 he might expect. (Likewise for item 1 with my 22 versus his likely average of about 51 and item 2 with 44 vs. roughly 51.) 

Based on this reasoning I propose to give Player 2 the “low‐value” items for me (items 1, 2, 3, and 5) largely in full or near full quantity, while keeping most of item 4. In particular, if I offer him:
 • 2 of item 1 (leaving me 3),
 • 5 of item 2 (leaving me 3),
 • all 3 of item 3,
 • 1 of item 4 (leaving me 4),
 • all 8 of item 5,
then his “bundle” by my estimate would sum to: 
 • item 1: 2 × ~51 = ~102,
 • item 2: 5 × ~51 = ~255,
 • item 3: 3 × ~51 = ~153,
 • item 4: 1 × ~51 = ~51,
 • item 5: 8 × ~51 = ~408,
a total “expected” value around 102 + 255 + 153 + 51 + 408 ≈ 969. 

Meanwhile, my retained bundle is:
 • item 1: 3 × 22 = 66,
 • item 2: 3 × 44 = 132,
 • item 4: 4 × 77 = 308,
(for a total of 66 + 132 + 308 = 506) and I get no units of items 3 and 5 (which I value less). 

Thus, I get 506 (well above my outside offer of 378) while Player 2’s package, by my expectations, is generous enough (in the neighborhood of his likely outside alternative on average). Being early in negotiations (round 1 with no discounting yet), this offer is designed to leave room to adjust if necessary but gives a good initial proposal that “anchors” negotiations near a mutually beneficial region.

So I now submit my counteroffer as follows:

Step 2. Choosing which items to offer:
 • Since my value for item 3 is very low (8 per unit) while an “average” opponent (drawn uniformly from 1…101) might expect about 51 per unit on average, item 3 is an ideal “concession” to help induce acceptance.

 • However, because the opponent’s outside offer is drawn from 1 up to their full‐valuation (which, for an expected full total of about 1275, gives an average reservation around 638), I must offer them a bundle whose expected value (from their perspective) is high enough that they won’t prefer to walk away.

 • If I were to give Player 2 all 6 units of item 3, then from my perspective I’m “losing” 6×8 = 48 value, while from Player 2’s expected viewpoint (assuming roughly 51 per unit) they’d get about 6×51 = 306. However, roughly 306 in expected value is likely too low compared to what they might get by walking away (around 600+ on average).

To “cover” the difference (roughly 330–340 in expected value), adding about 7 units of item 4 (7×51 ≈ 357) to the offer on top of all of item 3 gives an expected total near 306 + 357 = 663.
